Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
PRFB FELLOWSHIP: DEVELOPMENT OF NANOPARTICLE-BASED SENSORS WITH A NOVEL MICROSCOPIC TOOL

Nanomaterials are often functionalized with biological ligands to enable their use as sensors of biological activity. However, the intricacies of nano-bio interactions are poorly understood, which hampers designing nanomaterial-based sensors. To fill the need for the simultaneous study of nanoparticles and biomolecules, the proposal awardee will construct a novel instrument for such a purpose. This instrument will be used for the characterization of high-sensitivity synthetic sensors, whose preparation depends on proper biomolecule-nanoparticle conjugation. The design of synthetic sensors based on nanoparticle-biomolecule hybrids is promising for areas in need of high-specificity sensing tools, such as label-free detection of molecules within a cell, inexpensive medical diagnostic tools, and nanoscale therapeutics.

A significant subset of the work to be done will be dedicated to the broader impacts of the awardee?s research proposal. The awardee will participate in conference committees dedicated to advancing the participation of minority groups in science via peer-to-peer mentorship. To increase awareness of underrepresentation in the sciences locally, the awardee will found a chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans (SACNAS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Through SACNAS at MIT, the awardee will organize and lead activities that encourage pre-college students to consider careers in STEM. Lastly, the awardee will write and submit a grant to hold an international conference on the topic of low-dimensional nanomaterials and nanostructures. This conference will focus on increasing dialogue between researchers in North, Central, and South America by encouraging discussions in nanomaterial science that can be carried out in resource-limited countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanomaterials are of a similar size to the molecular entities that govern life within cells and are therefore well-suited to studying life at the sub-cellular scale. For this reason, there has been a rapid emergence in the use of nanomaterials for biomedical applications including the development of high-sensitivity and high-specificity synthetic sensors of biological activity. Nanomaterials have unique properties that make them useful for such applications. In particular, semiconducting single-wall carbon nanotubes are excellent candidates for the basis of nano-sensor development, as they are very photo-stable and transmit their signal in an optical window where tissues, cells, blood, and other biological samples are transparent. Ingenious functionalization of SWNT with polymers can impart sensing capabilities to SWNT, such that the SWNT-polymer conjugate produces a signature SWNT-mediated intensity and wavelength shift in the presence of a specific target molecule. However, the rational design of SWNT-based sensors that produce high-specificity optical signals is limited by a poor understanding of the fundamental polymer-nano interactions that lead to high-specificity signals. Existing optical tools have insufficient overlap to study both polymers and nanomaterials simultaneously, which is increasingly necessary to advance fields of research that hinge on polymer-nanoparticle interactions such as the design of SWNT-based sensors.

To fill the need for concurrent characterization of nanoparticles and polymers, combined two commonly used microscopy techniques into a single novel instrument: one for the study of polymers, and the other for the study of nanoparticles. These SWNT-polymer hybrids are synthetically engineered antibodies with high-specificity for a particular target by providing a strong near-infrared optical signal in the presence of the target molecule. The polymer serves a dual purpose: To bestow high-selectivity towards a particular target molecule, and to mask the hydrophobic and potentially toxic character of the SWNT. Reducing SWNT hydrophobicity in this manner makes the synthetic antibody water soluble, very stable, and nontoxic, which are all essential for the introduction of synthetic antibodies into cells and living systems. This microscopy platform enabled direct quantification of how our sensors provide molecular specificity for biological analytes with synthetic polymers, and enabled label-free detection of proteins secreted from a single cell.

 

The work completed in this project has produced a microscopic tool that enables concurrent monitoring of SWNT fluorescence and the behavior of the polymer, which was used to design and characterize synthetic antibodies for the detection of proteins secreted from a live cell. The detection of unlabeled proteins can yield many benefits. For instance, a fundamental trademark of diseased cells is a reprogrammed cellular metabolism in response to the imbalances caused by, for example, cancer’s increased cellular proliferation rate, or HIV’s infection. This altered cellular metabolism provides biochemical markers in the form of over- or under-expressed proteins, and leads to a marked cellular imbalance of a variety of proteins for which a real-time sensor would be valuable.  The synthetic sensors and accompanying microscopic platform to visualize sensor signals have produced a robust diagnostic tool for early detection of diseases and infections where they first originate: in cellular metabolic imbalances.
